title: RL33226
content: Since FY1989, Congress has allocated approximately $271 billion (in constant 2008 dollars) for disaster assistance through 34 appropriations measures, mainly supplemental acts following major catastrophes in the United States. The average annual funding over the 20-year period was $12 billion in current dollars, with a median of $2.7 billion. The mean annual funding in constant dollars was $13.6 billion, with a median of $3.8 billion. Disasters in 2001 and 2005 were particularly expensive, with supplemental appropriations exceeding $26 billion in FY2001 and FY2002. In FY2001 and FY2002, supplemental appropriations for disaster assistance exceeded $26 billion, mainly for recovery after the September 11, 2001 attacks. Following Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, and Wilma in FY2005 and FY2006, appropriations reached a record high. From FY2005 to FY2008, Congress allocated over $130 billion, almost 60% of the total since FY1989. In the 110th Congress, four measures provided around $41 billion for disaster relief, with P.L. 110-28 and P.L. 110-116 allocating $7.6 billion and $3.4 billion respectively for Hurricane Katrina recovery. In FY2001 and FY2002, supplemental appropriations for disaster assistance exceeded $26 billion, mainly for recovery after the September 11, 2001 attacks. Following Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, and Wilma in FY2005 and FY2006, appropriations reached a record high. From FY2005 to FY2008, Congress allocated over $130 billion, almost 60% of the total since FY1989. In the 110th Congress, four measures provided around $41 billion for disaster relief, with P.L. 110-116 and P.L. 110-329 allocating $6.355 billion and $21.4 billion respectively for continued recovery efforts related to Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, and Wilma, and other disasters. The Department of Housing and Urban Development's Community Development Fund received $6.5 billion for disaster relief in 2008. Other funding included $135 million for wildfire suppression and $100 million for the American Red Cross. This report summarizes emergency supplemental appropriations legislation enacted since 1989 for disaster relief efforts. This report summarizes emergency disaster assistance appropriations for disaster relief, repair of federal facilities, and hazard mitigation activities. It excludes counterterrorism, law enforcement, and national security appropriations. Supplemental appropriations have been enacted as stand-alone legislation, while some emergency disaster relief funding has been included in regular appropriations measures. Disaster relief funding is enacted through regular appropriations measures, continuing resolutions, or omnibus legislation. In response to hurricanes in 2005, the 109th Congress passed four emergency supplemental appropriations bills. Two were for Hurricane Katrina in Florida, Alabama, Louisiana, and Mississippi. In response to hurricanes in 2005, the 109th Congress passed four emergency supplemental appropriations bills, providing $62.3 billion for emergency response and recovery needs in Louisiana and Mississippi. The funding was primarily allocated to the Disaster Relief Fund administered by FEMA. Additionally, the FY2006 appropriations legislation for the Department of Defense rescinded $34 billion in funds previously appropriated and appropriated $29 billion for the restoration of federal facilities damaged by the hurricanes. Congress also agreed to an Administration request for further funding of $19.3 billion in supplemental legislation. The 109th Congress passed four emergency supplemental appropriations bills totaling $62.3 billion for hurricane response and recovery in Louisiana and Mississippi. An additional $19.3 billion was appropriated in supplemental legislation for further funding. P.L. 110-28 provided $120 billion in emergency funding for Iraq, Afghanistan, and Gulf Coast relief, with $6.9 billion allocated for continued assistance. After the 2005 hurricanes, Congress provided $5.9 billion in emergency assistance, with $3 billion allocated for the Louisiana Road Home program and $2.9 billion for disaster relief. The total amount of supplemental funding surpassed $130 billion. Funds were also rescinded from various departments and agencies. The 110th Congress enacted funding changes transferring $712 million from FEMA to Small Business Administration for disaster loans. The Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 (P.L. 110-252) included funding for economic development, housing programs, and disaster assistance for the Corps of Engineers. Another supplemental, the Consolidated Security, Disaster Assistance, and Continuing Appropriations Act, 2009, was passed later. The Consolidated Security, Disaster Assistance, and Continuing Appropriations Act, 2009 (P.L. 110-329) provided ongoing disaster relief for the 2005 hurricane season, including $85 million for the Disaster Housing Assistance program. The total amount allocated for disaster relief was approximately $1.3 billion. In FY2008, various reports were published on Authorization and Appropriations, including Federal Stafford Act Disaster Assistance and FY2007 Supplemental Appropriations. Additionally, FY2008 Spring Supplemental Appropriations and FY2009 Bridge Appropriations were made for Military Operations and International Affairs.
